title.narrative: Strengthening Public Health Capacity to Respond to Myanmar's Disease Transition

description.narrative: Effective UPH operational capacity including project and financial management | Active professional linkages with health institutes in other South-South collaborations
Enhanced research and evidence-based policy analysis to inform the government's response to the health transition in Myanmar
Greater knowledge among 1,500 policy makers and public health implementers across Myanmar on how to address the rising burden of NCDs
Increased in-country policy dialogue and consultation with a wide range of Myanmar stakeholders on the rising challenges of NCDs
Stronger UPH academic capacity (90 academic staff) to deliver high quality teaching and research, guided by a clear institutional strategy

The overall objective of this project is to contribute to the process of health reform in Myanmar so that the goals of equitable and universal healthcare can be achieved.
Moreover, the specific goal is to strengthen the University of Public Health and wider health stakeholders to support evidence-based policy and improved health services, particularly in preparation for the transition towards non-communicable diseases in Myanmar.

University of Public Health and 125 staff; Myanmar's health authorities including 1,500 staff; other health institutes including Co-applicants (100 staff); 1,500 health students. Final beneficiaries are 24 million people who suffer from NCDs, are at high risk of contracting NCDs, or provide household support to those with NCDs; 88,975 health workers.

mailing-address.narrative: Tavis House, 1-6 Tavistock Square, London WC1H 9NA
